newsitem.title: TAJIKISTAN: Armed clashes rock capital of Tajikistan.
newsitem.headline: Armed clashes rock capital of Tajikistan.

text.p: Fighting erupted between two rival armed bands in a northern district of the Tajik capital Dushanbe on Saturday, witnesses said, threatening a shaky peace in the former Soviet republic.
A Reuter correspondent was turned back from the area of the fighting by police but he said he heard small arms fire and an explosion.
The former Soviet republic is trying to emerge from a four-year civil war following a peace agreement signed in June.

Yakub Salimov, a senior tax official and a nominally pro-government commander, said by telephone the fighting involved his own armed group and men belonging to an elite unit of Interior Ministry troops led by commander Sufrob Kasimov.
"They are shooting here but I have not heard of any casualties so far," he told Reuters.
There was no immediate comment from Kasimov.
Tajik military sources said the fighting was linked to a vendetta between local armed groups, but there was no official reaction to the fighting.
A maverick government commander, Colonel Makhmud Khudoyberdyev, stepped up the pressure by saying he wanted Kasimov to leave Dushanbe.

"If Kasimov does not leave Dushanbe by the end of the day, I will move my armour to Fakhrobad (south of Dushanbe)," Khudoyberdyev told Reuters by telephone from his base near Kurgan Tyube in southern Tajikistan.
He said 700 armed "volunteers" had already taken control of a government checkpoint 30 km (19 miles) south of Dushanbe in the Fakhrobad Valley. This could not be independently confirmed.
Khudoyberdyev, who commands an elite armoured brigade, has mutinied twice. His relations with the government are ambivalent.
The Tajik government and the republic's armed Islamic opposition signed a peace agreement in June to end the civil war which killed tens of thousands of people and displaced many more.
But Khudoyberdyev said last week the return of up to 500 armed Islamic opposition guerrillas to Dushanbe, which the accord provides for, would provoke fresh bloodshed.
A ceasefire has largely held since December but a kaleidoscopic array of armed bands threaten stability in the impoverished republic of 5.7 million which borders Afghanistan and China.
